member.name: T:FlaUI.Core.AutomationElements.Calendar
member.summary: Class to interact with a calendar element. Not supported for Windows Forms calendar.

member.name: M:FlaUI.Core.AutomationElements.Calendar.#ctor(FlaUI.Core.FrameworkAutomationElementBase)
member.summary: Creates a element.

member.name: P:FlaUI.Core.AutomationElements.Calendar.SelectedDates
member.summary: Gets the selected dates in the calendar. For Win32 multiple selection calendar the returned array has two dates, the first date and the last date of the selected range. For WPF calendar the returned array contains all selected dates.

member.name: M:FlaUI.Core.AutomationElements.Calendar.SelectDate(System.DateTime)
member.summary: Deselects other selected dates and selects the specified date.

member.name: M:FlaUI.Core.AutomationElements.Calendar.SelectRange(System.DateTime[])
member.summary: For WPF calendar with SelectionMode="MultipleRange" this method deselects other selected dates and selects the specified range. For any other type of SelectionMode it deselects other selected dates and selects only the last date in the range. For Win32 multiple selection calendar the "dates" parameter should contain two dates, the first and the last date of the range to be selected. For Win32 single selection calendar this method selects only the second date from the "dates" array. For WPF calendar all dates should be specified in the "dates" parameter, not only the first and the last date of the range.

member.name: M:FlaUI.Core.AutomationElements.Calendar.AddToSelection(System.DateTime)
member.summary: For WPF calendar with SelectionMode="MultipleRange" this method adds the specified date to current selection. For any other type of SelectionMode it deselects other selected dates and selects the specified date. This method is supported only for WPF calendar.

member.name: M:FlaUI.Core.AutomationElements.Calendar.AddRangeToSelection(System.DateTime[])
member.summary: For WPF calendar with SelectionMode="MultipleRange" this method adds the specified range to current selection. For any other type of SelectionMode it deselects other selected dates and selects only the last date in the range. This method is supported only for WPF calendar.

member.name: P:FlaUI.Core.Capturing.InfoOverlay.OverlayStringFormat
member.summary: The string to use for the overlay. Has some variables which are automatically replaced. The variables are: - dt: The current systems datetime, can additionally be followed with a .net format string. - rt: The timespan since the recording started See also . - name: The machine name of the current system. - cpu: The cpu usage. - mem.p.tot: The physical total memory. - mem.p.free: The physical free memory. - mem.p.used: The physical used memory. - mem.p.free.perc: The physical free memory in percent. - mem.p.used.perc: The physical used memory in percent. - mem.v.tot: The virtual total memory. - mem.v.free: The virtual free memory. - mem.v.used: The virtual used memory. - mem.v.free.perc: The virtual free memory in percent. - mem.v.used.perc: The virtual used memory in percent.

member.name: T:FlaUI.Core.Definitions.LiveSetting
member.summary: Describes the notification characteristics of a particular live region.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.Definitions.LiveSetting.Off
member.summary: The element does not send notifications if the content of the live region has changed.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.Definitions.LiveSetting.Polite
member.summary: The element sends non-interruptive notifications if the content of the live region has changed. With this setting, UI Automation clients and assistive technologies are expected to not interrupt the user to inform of changes to the live region.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.Definitions.LiveSetting.Assertive
member.summary: The element sends interruptive notifications if the content of the live region has changed. With this setting, UI Automation clients and assistive technologies are expected to interrupt the user to inform of changes to the live region.

member.name: T:FlaUI.Core.Definitions.NotificationKind
member.summary: Defines values that indicate the type of a notification event, and a hint to the listener about the processing of the event.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.Definitions.NotificationKind.ItemAdded
member.summary: The current element and/or the container has had something added to it that should be presented to the user.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.Definitions.NotificationKind.ItemRemoved
member.summary: The current element has had something removed from inside of it that should be presented to the user.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.Definitions.NotificationKind.ActionCompleted
member.summary: The current element has a notification that an action was completed.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.Definitions.NotificationKind.ActionAborted
member.summary: The current element has a notification that an action was aborted.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.Definitions.NotificationKind.Other
member.summary: The current element has a notification not an add, remove, completed, or aborted action.

member.name: T:FlaUI.Core.Definitions.NotificationProcessing
member.summary: Defines values that indicate how a notification should be processed.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.Definitions.NotificationProcessing.ImportantAll
member.summary: These notifications should be presented to the user as soon as possible and all of the notifications from this source should be delivered to the user.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.Definitions.NotificationProcessing.ImportantMostRecent
member.summary: These notifications should be presented to the user as soon as possible. The most recent notification from this source should be delivered to the user because it supersedes all of the other notifications.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.Definitions.NotificationProcessing.All
member.summary: These notifications should be presented to the user when possible. All of the notifications from this source should be delivered to the user.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.Definitions.NotificationProcessing.MostRecent
member.summary: These notifications should be presented to the user when possible. The most recent notification from this source should be delivered to the user because it supersedes all of the other notifications.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.Definitions.NotificationProcessing.CurrentThenMostRecent
member.summary: These notifications should be presented to the user when possible. Dont interrupt the current notification for this one. If new notifications come in from the same source while the current notification is being presented, keep the most recent and ignore the rest until the current processing is completed. Then, use the most recent message as the current message.

member.name: T:FlaUI.Core.Definitions.ScrollAmount
member.summary: Contains values that specify the direction and distance to scroll.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.Definitions.ScrollAmount.LargeDecrement
member.summary: Scrolling is done in large decrements, equivalent to pressing the PAGE UP key or clicking on a blank part of a scroll bar. If one page up is not a relevant amount for the control and no scroll bar exists, the value represents an amount equal to the current visible window.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.Definitions.ScrollAmount.SmallDecrement
member.summary: Scrolling is done in small decrements, equivalent to pressing an arrow key or clicking the arrow button on a scroll bar.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.Definitions.ScrollAmount.NoAmount
member.summary: No scrolling is done.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.Definitions.ScrollAmount.LargeIncrement
member.summary: Scrolling is done in large increments, equivalent to pressing the PAGE DOWN or PAGE UP key or clicking on a blank part of a scroll bar. If one page is not a relevant amount for the control and no scroll bar exists, the value represents an amount equal to the current visible window.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.Definitions.ScrollAmount.SmallIncrement
member.summary: Scrolling is done in small increments, equivalent to pressing an arrow key or clicking the arrow button on a scroll bar.

member.name: T:FlaUI.Core.Definitions.StructureChangeType
member.summary: Contains values that specify the type of change in the Microsoft UI Automation tree structure.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.Definitions.StructureChangeType.ChildAdded
member.summary: A child element was added to the UI Automation element tree.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.Definitions.StructureChangeType.ChildRemoved
member.summary: A child element was removed from the UI Automation element tree.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.Definitions.StructureChangeType.ChildrenInvalidated
member.summary: Child elements were invalidated in the UI Automation element tree. This might mean that one or more child elements were added or removed, or a combination of both This value can also indicate that one subtree in the UI was substituted for another. For example, the entire contents of a dialog box changed at once, or the view of a list changed because an Explorer-type application navigated to another location. The exact meaning depends on the UI Automation provider implementation.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.Definitions.StructureChangeType.ChildrenBulkAdded
member.summary: Child elements were added in bulk to the UI Automation element tree.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.Definitions.StructureChangeType.ChildrenBulkRemoved
member.summary: Child elements were removed in bulk from the UI Automation element tree.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.Definitions.StructureChangeType.ChildrenReordered
member.summary: The order of child elements has changed in the UI Automation element tree. Child elements may or may not have been added or removed.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.SystemMetric.SM_ARRANGE
member.summary: The flags that specify how the system arranged minimized windows. For more information, see the Remarks section in this topic.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.SystemMetric.SM_CLEANBOOT
member.summary: The value that specifies how the system is started: 0 Normal boot 1 Fail-safe boot 2 Fail-safe with network boot A fail-safe boot (also called SafeBoot, Safe Mode, or Clean Boot) bypasses the user startup files.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.SystemMetric.SM_CMONITORS
member.summary: The number of display monitors on a desktop. For more information, see the Remarks section in this topic.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.SystemMetric.SM_CMOUSEBUTTONS
member.summary: The number of buttons on a mouse, or zero if no mouse is installed.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.SystemMetric.SM_CONVERTIBLESLATEMODE
member.summary: Reflects the state of the laptop or slate mode, 0 for Slate Mode and non-zero otherwise. When this system metric changes, the system sends a broadcast message via WM_SETTINGCHANGE with "ConvertibleSlateMode" in the LPARAM. Note that this system metric doesn't apply to desktop PCs. In that case, use GetAutoRotationState.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.SystemMetric.SM_CXBORDER
member.summary: The width of a window border, in pixels. This is equivalent to the SM_CXEDGE value for windows with the 3-D look.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.SystemMetric.SM_CXCURSOR
member.summary: The width of a cursor, in pixels. The system cannot create cursors of other sizes.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.SystemMetric.SM_CXDLGFRAME
member.summary: This value is the same as SM_CXFIXEDFRAME.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.SystemMetric.SM_CXDRAG
member.summary: The number of pixels on either side of a mouse-down point that the mouse pointer can move before a drag operation begins. This allows the user to click and release the mouse button easily without unintentionally starting a drag operation. If this value is negative, it is subtracted from the left of the mouse-down point and added to the right of it.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.SystemMetric.SM_CXEDGE
member.summary: The width of a 3-D border, in pixels. This metric is the 3-D counterpart of SM_CXBORDER.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.SystemMetric.SM_CXFRAME
member.summary: This value is the same as SM_CXSIZEFRAME.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.SystemMetric.SM_CXFULLSCREEN
member.summary: The width of the client area for a full-screen window on the primary display monitor, in pixels. To get the coordinates of the portion of the screen that is not obscured by the system taskbar or by application desktop toolbars, call the SystemParametersInfo function with the SPI_GETWORKAREA value.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.SystemMetric.SM_CXHSCROLL
member.summary: The width of the arrow bitmap on a horizontal scroll bar, in pixels.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.SystemMetric.SM_CXHTHUMB
member.summary: The width of the thumb box in a horizontal scroll bar, in pixels.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.SystemMetric.SM_CXICON
member.summary: The default width of an icon, in pixels. The LoadIcon function can load only icons with the dimensions that SM_CXICON and SM_CYICON specifies.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.SystemMetric.SM_CXICONSPACING
member.summary: The width of a grid cell for items in large icon view, in pixels. Each item fits into a rectangle of size SM_CXICONSPACING by SM_CYICONSPACING when arranged. This value is always greater than or equal to SM_CXICON.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.SystemMetric.SM_CXMAXIMIZED
member.summary: The default width, in pixels, of a maximized top-level window on the primary display monitor.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.SystemMetric.SM_CXMAXTRACK
member.summary: The default maximum width of a window that has a caption and sizing borders, in pixels. This metric refers to the entire desktop. The user cannot drag the window frame to a size larger than these dimensions. A window can override this value by processing the WM_GETMINMAXINFO message.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.SystemMetric.SM_CXMENUCHECK
member.summary: The width of the default menu check-mark bitmap, in pixels.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.SystemMetric.SM_CXMENUSIZE
member.summary: The width of menu bar buttons, such as the child window close button that is used in the multiple document interface, in pixels.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.SystemMetric.SM_CXMIN
member.summary: The minimum width of a window, in pixels.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.SystemMetric.SM_CXMINIMIZED
member.summary: The width of a minimized window, in pixels.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.SystemMetric.SM_CXMINSPACING
member.summary: The width of a grid cell for a minimized window, in pixels. Each minimized window fits into a rectangle this size when arranged. This value is always greater than or equal to SM_CXMINIMIZED.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.SystemMetric.SM_CXMINTRACK
member.summary: The minimum tracking width of a window, in pixels. The user cannot drag the window frame to a size smaller than these dimensions. A window can override this value by processing the WM_GETMINMAXINFO message.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.SystemMetric.SM_CXSCREEN
member.summary: The width of the screen of the primary display monitor, in pixels. This is the same value obtained by calling GetDeviceCaps as follows: GetDeviceCaps( hdcPrimaryMonitor, HORZRES).

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.SystemMetric.SM_CXSIZE
member.summary: The width of a button in a window caption or title bar, in pixels.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.SystemMetric.SM_CXSMICON
member.summary: The recommended width of a small icon, in pixels. Small icons typically appear in window captions and in small icon view.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.SystemMetric.SM_CXSMSIZE
member.summary: The width of small caption buttons, in pixels.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.SystemMetric.SM_CXVIRTUALSCREEN
member.summary: The width of the virtual screen, in pixels. The virtual screen is the bounding rectangle of all display monitors. The SM_XVIRTUALSCREEN metric is the coordinates for the left side of the virtual screen.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.SystemMetric.SM_CXVSCROLL
member.summary: The width of a vertical scroll bar, in pixels.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.SystemMetric.SM_CYBORDER
member.summary: The height of a window border, in pixels. This is equivalent to the SM_CYEDGE value for windows with the 3-D look.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.SystemMetric.SM_CYCAPTION
member.summary: The height of a caption area, in pixels.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.SystemMetric.SM_CYCURSOR
member.summary: The height of a cursor, in pixels. The system cannot create cursors of other sizes.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.SystemMetric.SM_CYDLGFRAME
member.summary: This value is the same as SM_CYFIXEDFRAME.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.SystemMetric.SM_CYDRAG
member.summary: The number of pixels above and below a mouse-down point that the mouse pointer can move before a drag operation begins. This allows the user to click and release the mouse button easily without unintentionally starting a drag operation. If this value is negative, it is subtracted from above the mouse-down point and added below it.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.SystemMetric.SM_CYEDGE
member.summary: The height of a 3-D border, in pixels. This is the 3-D counterpart of SM_CYBORDER.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.SystemMetric.SM_CYFRAME
member.summary: This value is the same as SM_CYSIZEFRAME.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.SystemMetric.SM_CYFULLSCREEN
member.summary: The height of the client area for a full-screen window on the primary display monitor, in pixels. To get the coordinates of the portion of the screen not obscured by the system taskbar or by application desktop toolbars, call the SystemParametersInfo function with the SPI_GETWORKAREA value.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.SystemMetric.SM_CYHSCROLL
member.summary: The height of a horizontal scroll bar, in pixels.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.SystemMetric.SM_CYICON
member.summary: The default height of an icon, in pixels. The LoadIcon function can load only icons with the dimensions SM_CXICON and SM_CYICON.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.SystemMetric.SM_CYICONSPACING
member.summary: The height of a grid cell for items in large icon view, in pixels. Each item fits into a rectangle of size SM_CXICONSPACING by SM_CYICONSPACING when arranged. This value is always greater than or equal to SM_CYICON.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.SystemMetric.SM_CYKANJIWINDOW
member.summary: For double byte character set versions of the system, this is the height of the Kanji window at the bottom of the screen, in pixels.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.SystemMetric.SM_CYMAXIMIZED
member.summary: The default height, in pixels, of a maximized top-level window on the primary display monitor.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.SystemMetric.SM_CYMAXTRACK
member.summary: The default maximum height of a window that has a caption and sizing borders, in pixels. This metric refers to the entire desktop. The user cannot drag the window frame to a size larger than these dimensions. A window can override this value by processing the WM_GETMINMAXINFO message.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.SystemMetric.SM_CYMENU
member.summary: The height of a single-line menu bar, in pixels.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.SystemMetric.SM_CYMENUCHECK
member.summary: The height of the default menu check-mark bitmap, in pixels.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.SystemMetric.SM_CYMENUSIZE
member.summary: The height of menu bar buttons, such as the child window close button that is used in the multiple document interface, in pixels.

member.summary: The minimum height of a window, in pixels.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.SystemMetric.SM_CYMINIMIZED
member.summary: The height of a minimized window, in pixels.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.SystemMetric.SM_CYMINSPACING
member.summary: The height of a grid cell for a minimized window, in pixels. Each minimized window fits into a rectangle this size when arranged. This value is always greater than or equal to SM_CYMINIMIZED.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.SystemMetric.SM_CYMINTRACK
member.summary: The minimum tracking height of a window, in pixels. The user cannot drag the window frame to a size smaller than these dimensions. A window can override this value by processing the WM_GETMINMAXINFO message.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.SystemMetric.SM_CYSCREEN
member.summary: The height of the screen of the primary display monitor, in pixels. This is the same value obtained by calling GetDeviceCaps as follows: GetDeviceCaps( hdcPrimaryMonitor, VERTRES).

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.SystemMetric.SM_CYSIZE
member.summary: The height of a button in a window caption or title bar, in pixels.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.SystemMetric.SM_CYSMCAPTION
member.summary: The height of a small caption, in pixels.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.SystemMetric.SM_CYSMICON
member.summary: The recommended height of a small icon, in pixels. Small icons typically appear in window captions and in small icon view.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.SystemMetric.SM_CYSMSIZE
member.summary: The height of small caption buttons, in pixels.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.SystemMetric.SM_CYVIRTUALSCREEN
member.summary: The height of the virtual screen, in pixels. The virtual screen is the bounding rectangle of all display monitors. The SM_YVIRTUALSCREEN metric is the coordinates for the top of the virtual screen.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.SystemMetric.SM_CYVSCROLL
member.summary: The height of the arrow bitmap on a vertical scroll bar, in pixels.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.SystemMetric.SM_CYVTHUMB
member.summary: The height of the thumb box in a vertical scroll bar, in pixels.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.SystemMetric.SM_DBCSENABLED
member.summary: Nonzero if User32.dll supports DBCS; otherwise, 0.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.SystemMetric.SM_DEBUG
member.summary: Nonzero if the debug version of User.exe is installed; otherwise, 0.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.SystemMetric.SM_DIGITIZER
member.summary: Nonzero if the current operating system is Windows 7 or Windows Server 2008 R2 and the Tablet PC Input service is started; otherwise, 0. The return value is a bitmask that specifies the type of digitizer input supported by the device. For more information, see Remarks. Windows Server 2008, Windows Vista and Windows XP/2000: This value is not supported.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.SystemMetric.SM_IMMENABLED
member.summary: Nonzero if Input Method Manager/Input Method Editor features are enabled; otherwise, 0. SM_IMMENABLED indicates whether the system is ready to use a Unicode-based IME on a Unicode application. To ensure that a language-dependent IME works, check SM_DBCSENABLED and the system ANSI code page. Otherwise the ANSI-to-Unicode conversion may not be performed correctly, or some components like fonts or registry settings may not be present.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.SystemMetric.SM_MAXIMUMTOUCHES
member.summary: Nonzero if there are digitizers in the system; otherwise, 0. SM_MAXIMUMTOUCHES returns the aggregate maximum of the maximum number of contacts supported by every digitizer in the system. If the system has only single-touch digitizers, the return value is 1. If the system has multi-touch digitizers, the return value is the number of simultaneous contacts the hardware can provide. Windows Server 2008, Windows Vista and Windows XP/2000: This value is not supported.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.SystemMetric.SM_MEDIACENTER
member.summary: Nonzero if the current operating system is the Windows XP, Media Center Edition, 0 if not.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.SystemMetric.SM_MENUDROPALIGNMENT
member.summary: Nonzero if drop-down menus are right-aligned with the corresponding menu-bar item; 0 if the menus are left-aligned.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.SystemMetric.SM_MIDEASTENABLED
member.summary: Nonzero if the system is enabled for Hebrew and Arabic languages, 0 if not.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.SystemMetric.SM_MOUSEPRESENT
member.summary: Nonzero if a mouse is installed; otherwise, 0. This value is rarely zero, because of support for virtual mice and because some systems detect the presence of the port instead of the presence of a mouse.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.SystemMetric.SM_MOUSEHORIZONTALWHEELPRESENT
member.summary: Nonzero if a mouse with a horizontal scroll wheel is installed; otherwise 0.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.SystemMetric.SM_MOUSEWHEELPRESENT
member.summary: Nonzero if a mouse with a vertical scroll wheel is installed; otherwise 0.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.SystemMetric.SM_NETWORK
member.summary: The least significant bit is set if a network is present; otherwise, it is cleared. The other bits are reserved for future use.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.SystemMetric.SM_PENWINDOWS
member.summary: Nonzero if the Microsoft Windows for Pen computing extensions are installed; zero otherwise.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.SystemMetric.SM_REMOTECONTROL
member.summary: This system metric is used in a Terminal Services environment to determine if the current Terminal Server session is being remotely controlled. Its value is nonzero if the current session is remotely controlled; otherwise, 0. You can use terminal services management tools such as Terminal Services Manager (tsadmin.msc) and shadow.exe to control a remote session. When a session is being remotely controlled, another user can view the contents of that session and potentially interact with it.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.SystemMetric.SM_REMOTESESSION
member.summary: This system metric is used in a Terminal Services environment. If the calling process is associated with a Terminal Services client session, the return value is nonzero. If the calling process is associated with the Terminal Services console session, the return value is 0. Windows Server 2003 and Windows XP: The console session is not necessarily the physical console. For more information, see WTSGetActiveConsoleSessionId.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.SystemMetric.SM_SAMEDISPLAYFORMAT
member.summary: Nonzero if all the display monitors have the same color format, otherwise, 0. Two displays can have the same bit depth, but different color formats. For example, the red, green, and blue pixels can be encoded with different numbers of bits, or those bits can be located in different places in a pixel color value.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.SystemMetric.SM_SECURE
member.summary: This system metric should be ignored; it always returns 0.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.SystemMetric.SM_SERVERR2
member.summary: The build number if the system is Windows Server 2003 R2; otherwise, 0.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.SystemMetric.SM_SHOWSOUNDS
member.summary: Nonzero if the user requires an application to present information visually in situations where it would otherwise present the information only in audible form; otherwise, 0.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.SystemMetric.SM_SHUTTINGDOWN
member.summary: Nonzero if the current session is shutting down; otherwise, 0. Windows 2000: This value is not supported.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.SystemMetric.SM_SLOWMACHINE
member.summary: Nonzero if the computer has a low-end (slow) processor; otherwise, 0.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.SystemMetric.SM_STARTER
member.summary: Nonzero if the current operating system is Windows 7 Starter Edition, Windows Vista Starter, or Windows XP Starter Edition; otherwise, 0.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.SystemMetric.SM_SWAPBUTTON
member.summary: Nonzero if the meanings of the left and right mouse buttons are swapped; otherwise, 0.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.SystemMetric.SM_SYSTEMDOCKED
member.summary: Reflects the state of the docking mode, 0 for Undocked Mode and non-zero otherwise. When this system metric changes, the system sends a broadcast message via WM_SETTINGCHANGE with "SystemDockMode" in the LPARAM.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.SystemMetric.SM_TABLETPC
member.summary: Nonzero if the current operating system is the Windows XP Tablet PC edition or if the current operating system is Windows Vista or Windows 7 and the Tablet PC Input service is started; otherwise, 0. The SM_DIGITIZER setting indicates the type of digitizer input supported by a device running Windows 7 or Windows Server 2008 R2. For more information, see Remarks.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.SystemMetric.SM_XVIRTUALSCREEN
member.summary: The coordinates for the left side of the virtual screen. The virtual screen is the bounding rectangle of all display monitors. The SM_CXVIRTUALSCREEN metric is the width of the virtual screen.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.SystemMetric.SM_YVIRTUALSCREEN
member.summary: The coordinates for the top of the virtual screen. The virtual screen is the bounding rectangle of all display monitors. The SM_CYVIRTUALSCREEN metric is the height of the virtual screen.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.TernaryRasterOperations.SRCINVERT

member.summary: Generic pointer type. This type never appears in pointer messages or pointer data. Some data query functions allow the caller to restrict the query to specific pointer type. The PT_POINTER type can be used in these functions to specify that the query is to include pointers of all types

member.name: T:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.PointerFlags
member.summary: Values that can appear in the pointerFlags field of the POINTER_INFO structure.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.PointerFlags.NONE
member.summary: Default.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.PointerFlags.NEW
member.summary: Indicates the arrival of a new pointer.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.PointerFlags.INRANGE
member.summary: Indicates that this pointer continues to exist. When this flag is not set, it indicates the pointer has left detection range. This flag is typically not set only when a hovering pointer leaves detection range (POINTER_FLAG_UPDATE is set) or when a pointer in contact with a window surface leaves detection range(POINTER_FLAG_UP is set).

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.PointerFlags.INCONTACT
member.summary: Indicates that this pointer is in contact with the digitizer surface. When this flag is not set, it indicates a hovering pointer.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.PointerFlags.FIRSTBUTTON
member.summary: Indicates a primary action, analogous to a left mouse button down. A touch pointer has this flag set when it is in contact with the digitizer surface. A pen pointer has this flag set when it is in contact with the digitizer surface with no buttons pressed. A mouse pointer has this flag set when the left mouse button is down.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.PointerFlags.SECONDBUTTON
member.summary: Indicates a secondary action, analogous to a right mouse button down. A touch pointer does not use this flag. A pen pointer has this flag set when it is in contact with the digitizer surface with the pen barrel button pressed. A mouse pointer has this flag set when the right mouse button is down.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.PointerFlags.THIRDBUTTON
member.summary: Analogous to a mouse wheel button down. A touch pointer does not use this flag. A pen pointer does not use this flag. A mouse pointer has this flag set when the mouse wheel button is down.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.PointerFlags.FOURTHBUTTON
member.summary: Analogous to a first extended mouse (XButton1) button down. A touch pointer does not use this flag. A pen pointer does not use this flag. A mouse pointer has this flag set when the first extended mouse(XBUTTON1) button is down.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.PointerFlags.FIFTHBUTTON
member.summary: Analogous to a first extended mouse (XButton2) button down. A touch pointer does not use this flag. A pen pointer does not use this flag. A mouse pointer has this flag set when the first extended mouse(XBUTTON2) button is down.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.PointerFlags.PRIMARY
member.summary: Indicates that this pointer has been designated as the primary pointer. A primary pointer is a single pointer that can perform actions beyond those available to non-primary pointers. For example, when a primary pointer makes contact with a window s surface, it may provide the window an opportunity to activate by sending it a WM_POINTERACTIVATE message. The primary pointer is identified from all current user interactions on the system (mouse, touch, pen, and so on). As such, the primary pointer might not be associated with your app.The first contact in a multi-touch interaction is set as the primary pointer.Once a primary pointer is identified, all contacts must be lifted before a new contact can be identified as a primary pointer.For apps that don't process pointer input, only the primary pointer's events are promoted to mouse events.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.PointerFlags.CONFIDENCE
member.summary: Confidence is a suggestion from the source device about whether the pointer represents an intended or accidental interaction, which is especially relevant for PT_TOUCH pointers where an accidental interaction (such as with the palm of the hand) can trigger input. The presence of this flag indicates that the source device has high confidence that this input is part of an intended interaction.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.PointerFlags.CANCELLED
member.summary: Indicates that the pointer is departing in an abnormal manner, such as when the system receives invalid input for the pointer or when a device with active pointers departs abruptly. If the application receiving the input is in a position to do so, it should treat the interaction as not completed and reverse any effects of the concerned pointer.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.PointerFlags.DOWN
member.summary: Indicates that this pointer transitioned to a down state; that is, it made contact with the digitizer surface.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.PointerFlags.UPDATE
member.summary: Indicates that this is a simple update that does not include pointer state changes.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.PointerFlags.UP
member.summary: Indicates that this pointer transitioned to an up state; that is, contact with the digitizer surface ended.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.PointerFlags.WHEEL
member.summary: Indicates input associated with a pointer wheel. For mouse pointers, this is equivalent to the action of the mouse scroll wheel (WM_MOUSEHWHEEL).

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.PointerFlags.HWHEEL
member.summary: Indicates input associated with a pointer h-wheel. For mouse pointers, this is equivalent to the action of the mouse horizontal scroll wheel (WM_MOUSEHWHEEL).

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.PointerFlags.CAPTURECHANGED
member.summary: Indicates that this pointer was captured by (associated with) another element and the original element has lost capture (see WM_POINTERCAPTURECHANGED).

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.PointerFlags.HASTRANSFORM
member.summary: Indicates that this pointer has an associated transform.

member.summary: The second button (see POINTER_FLAG_SECONDBUTTON) transitioned to a released state.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.PointerButtonChangeType.THIRDBUTTON_DOWN
member.summary: The third button (see POINTER_FLAG_THIRDBUTTON) transitioned to a pressed state.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.PointerButtonChangeType.THIRDBUTTON_UP
member.summary: The third button (see POINTER_FLAG_THIRDBUTTON) transitioned to a released state.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.PointerButtonChangeType.FOURTHBUTTON_DOWN
member.summary: The fourth button (see POINTER_FLAG_FOURTHBUTTON) transitioned to a pressed state.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.PointerButtonChangeType.FOURTHBUTTON_UP
member.summary: The fourth button (see POINTER_FLAG_FOURTHBUTTON) transitioned to a released state.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.PointerButtonChangeType.FIFTHBUTTON_DOWN
member.summary: The fifth button (see POINTER_FLAG_FIFTHBUTTON) transitioned to a pressed state.

member.name: F:FlaUI.Core.WindowsAPI.PointerButtonChangeType.FIFTHBUTTON_UP
member.summary: The fifth button (see POINTER_FLAG_FIFTHBUTTON) transitioned to a released state.
